entity: Office of the United Nations Representative to the Geneva International Discussions
entity_raw_name: 5. 	Office of the United Nations Representative to the Geneva International Discussions
source_file: A_80_6 (SECT. 3)_ADD.2_CLUSTER I_FASCICLE ADVANCE UNEDITED COPY FOR ACABQ.json

content.text: A. 	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission is mandated to support the Geneva International Discussions and the Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism under United Nations auspices in Gali, Georgia, by facilitating the participation of the United Nations in the international discussions in Geneva and the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism, and by liaising and coordinating with the relevant actors. The mission is also responsible for preparing, convening and facilitating, in consultation with the other Co-Chairs, the European Union and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), the sessions of the Geneva International Discussions as well as the periodic meetings of the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism.

The United Nations has continued to support the Geneva International Discussions on security and stability and the return of internally displaced persons and refugees, which commenced on 15 October 2008 in Geneva in accordance with the six-point agreement of 12 August 2008 and the implementing measures of 8 September 2008, mediated by the French Presidency of the European Union, following the hostilities of August 2008 (S/2009/254). In its resolution 1866 (2009), the Security Council welcomed the beginning of the discussions and requested the Secretary-General, through his Special Representative, to continue to fully support the process. The Secretary-General addressed a letter on this matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Georgia on 29 September 2009 and the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Georgia replied to the Secretary-General on 28 October 2009.

Against the background of the “Proposals for joint incident prevention and response mechanisms”, agreed to in Geneva on 18 February 2009, the Secretary-General, on 28 September 2009, addressed a letter to the President of the Security Council in which he stated that the United Nations would continue to support the Geneva International Discussions and the Mechanism through a limited number of personnel with the task of facilitating the United Nations participation in the international discussions in Geneva and in the Mechanism, and liaising and coordinating with the relevant actors.

In a letter dated 28 December 2009 addressed to the President of the Security Council, the Secretary-General noted that the United Nations would continue to provide support for the Geneva International Discussions and the work of the Mechanism. In a letter dated 25 February 2010 addressed to the President of the Security Council (S/2010/103), the Secretary-General conveyed his intention to appoint a United Nations Representative responsible for United Nations support for the Geneva International Discussions and the Mechanism. In a letter dated 2 May 2011 (S/2011/279), the President of the Security Council informed the Secretary-General that the members of the Security Council had taken note of his intention and of the information contained in his letter of 25 February 2010. In 2018, there was an additional exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council regarding the appointment of a United Nations Representative.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to advance the main agenda items of the Geneva International Discussions, including the non-use of force/international security arrangements and addressing the issue of internally displaced persons and refugees, in the context of the Discussions and the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the mission, in close partnership with the  other Co-Chairs, will continue  efforts to facilitate progress on key agenda items of  the  Discussions, and   ensure the regular meetings of the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism as result-oriented platforms for dialogue and conflict prevention.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a) 	Contributing to the objective of transitioning the Discussions from a conflict management to a conflict transformation and resolution process.
(b)	Addressing and making progress on central issues, including the non-use of force/international security arrangements and internally displaced persons and refugees.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	All stakeholders will continue to support the  Discussions  and the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism and the  engagement of the United Nations;
(b)	All  stakeholders   will  support efforts to  enhance the effectiveness of the Discussions;
(c)	The Co-Chairs will continue to collaborate closely to fulfil the mandate of the Discussions.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission coordinates with the European Union and OSCE Co-Chairs. It maintains  contact with the European Union Monitoring Mission in Georgia and OSCE, which jointly facilitate the Ergneti Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism and other relevant actors.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison,  the mission cooperates closely with entities within the United Nations system,  and other actors so as to coordinate and strengthen the role and contribution of the United Nations within the framework of the  Discussions and the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism, especially in addressing humanitarian issues.

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its activities, including engaging in advocacy for gender equality and promoting  the role of women in conflict resolution and peacebuilding, including within the framework of the Co-Chairs’ joint strategy and action plan on women and peace and security.
The mission will closely cooperate with UNOG in the implementation of the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy.
Programme performance in 2024
Continuation of efforts to achieve concrete results on key issues on the agenda of the Geneva International Discussions

Three rounds of the Discussions took place in 2024, on 4 and 5 April, 25 and 26 June and 5 and 6 November, respectively. The Co-Chairs organized three visits to Tbilisi, Moscow, Sukhumi and Tskhinvali, as well as a visit to Washington, D.C. and   New York. The Co-Chairs also briefed  the OSCE Permanent Council in Vienna on 24 October 2024. The mission undertook visits to Tbilisi, Zugdidi, Gali and Sukhumi to engage with relevant actors. Despite the mission’s efforts, no meetings of the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism took place due to persisting differences among key participants on its modalities. The Mission will continue its efforts aimed at resumption of the Mechanism.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 20).
Table 20 – Performance measure

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Advancing progress on the main agenda items of  the Geneva International Discussions and – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission contributed to ensuring the engagement of all participants in the Discussions and help prevent the resumption of hostilities. The target of progress  on the  agenda of the  Discussions could not be achieved, owing primarily to persistent differences in positions among the participants.

In 2026, the mission, in cooperation with the other Co-Chairs, will continue efforts to advance progress on substantive agenda items and ensure the regular functioning of the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism on the basis of the established principles and practices.
Lessons learned and planned change in 2026

The lesson for the mission was the  importance of continuous engagement with all stakeholders, including utilizing virtual and other means, as appropriate. In applying the lesson, such efforts will continue.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 21).
Table 21 – Performance measure

content.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 23 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 24 – Human resources
a Comprising Other level.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the mission amount to $1,803,500 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($1,478,900) for the continuation of six posts based in Geneva (1 Assistant Secretary-General, 1 P-5, 2 P-4, 1 P-3 and 1 General Service (Other level)) and one post based in Zugdidi, Georgia (P-3), as well as for operational costs ($324,600), comprising costs for consultants and consulting services ($3,300), official travel ($125,400), facilities and infrastructure ($134,700), ground transportation ($23,400), communications and information technology ($21,300) and other supplies, services and equipment ($16,500).

In 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts. Vacancy rates of 16.7 per cent and zero per cent have been applied to the estimates for international and national staff, respectively, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024.

The decrease in the requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to reduced requirements for civilian personnel, resulting from the application of a higher vacancy rate of 16.7 per cent for international staff, compared with the rate of 3.6 per cent applied in 2025, offset in part by the increased requirements for national staff due to  the application of a zero vacancy rate, compared with the rate of 3.6 per cent applied in 2025.
